intro: Pedicularis humilis, commonly known as the lesser marsh orchid, is a herbaceous perennial native to wetlands and mountainous regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, which includes many parasitic and hemiparasitic plants. The plant typically grows to a height of 20–60 cm, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are usually pink or purple, arranged in a spike and characterized by their spurred petals. Pedicularis humilis is often found in moist, calcareous soils and is adapted to thrive in cool, shaded environments.
